sect1.para: &ds389; supports synchronizing some user and group content from Microsoft's &ad;, so that Linux clients can use &ds389a; for their identity information without the normally required domain join process. This also allows &ds389a; to extend and use its other features with the data synchronised from &ad;.

sect2.title: Planning your synchronization topology
sect2.para: Due to how the synchronization works, only a single &ds389; and &ad; server are involved. The &ad; server must be a full Domain Controller, and not a Read Only Domain Controller (RODC). The Global Catalog is not required on the DC that is synchronized, as &ds389a; only replicates the content of a single forest in a domain.
You must first chooose the direction of your data flow. There are three options: from &ada; to &ds389a;, from &ds389a; to &ada;, or bi- directional.

note.title: No password synchronization
note.para: Passwords cannot be synchronised between &ds389a; and &ad;. This may change in the future, to support &ad; to &ds389a; password flow.

sect2.para: Your topology will look like the following diagram. The &ds389; and &ad; topologies may differ, but the most important factor is to have only a single connection between &ds389a; and &ad;. It is very important to account for this in your disaster recovery and backup plans for both &ds389a; and &ada;, to ensure that you correctly restore only a single replication connection between these topologies.

sect2.title: Prerequisites for &ad;
sect2.para: A security group that is granted the "Replicating Directory Changes" permission is required. For example, you have created a group named "Directory Server Sync". Follow the steps in the "How to grant the 'Replicating Directory Changes' permission for the Microsoft Metadirectory Services ADMA service account" ( to set this up.

warning.title: Strong security needed
warning.para: You should consider members of this group to be of equivalent security importance to Domain Administrators. Members of this group have the ability to read sensitive content from the Active Directory environment, so you should use strong, randomly-generated service account passwords for these accounts, and carefully audit membership to this group.

sect2.para: You should also create a service account that is a member of this group.

Your &ad; environment must have certificates configured for LDAPS to ensure that authentication between &ds389a; and &ada; is secure. Authentication with Generic Security Services API/Kerberos (GSSAPI/KRB) cannot be used.

sect2.title: Prerequisites for &ds389;
sect2.para: The &ds389; must have a backend database already configured with Organization Units (OUs) for entries to be synchronised into.

sect2.title: Creating an agreement from &ad; to &ds389;
sect2.para: The following example command, which is run on the &ds389;, creates a replication agreement from &ad; to &ds389;:
sect2.screen: &prompt.sudo;dsconf INSTANCE-NAME repl-winsync-agmt create --suffix dc=example,dc=com \ --host AD-HOSTNAME --port 636 --conn-protocol LDAPS \ --bind-dn "cn=SERVICE-ACCOUNT,cn=USERS,dc=AD,dc=EXAMPLE,dc=COM" \ --bind-passwd "PASSWORD" --win-subtree "cn=USERS,dc=AD,dc=EXAMPLE,dc=COM" \ --ds-subtree ou=AD,dc=EXAMPLE,dc=COM --one-way-sync fromWindows \ --sync-users=on --sync-groups=on --move-action delete \ --win-domain AD-DOMAIN adsync_agreement
